params.text:
• Use the Correct Word Order
  • Speak about the Present
  • Speak about the Past

Professional Writing

Sentence Structure

Language in Action
Professional Writing: Introduction

Welcome everyone! Today, we have 3 main topics:

You will learn how to:

1. Put words in the right order

  2. Talk about things that are happening now

  3. Discuss things that already happened
Use the Correct Word Order: Key Points

In English, we have a specific order for the words in a sentence.

This helps us understand the meaning clearly:
Subject-Verb:

• Every sentence needs a subject (the person or thing doing something) and a verb (the action). The subject usually comes first, then the verb.
  • Example: I work in an office. (I - subject, work - verb)
Simple Sentences:

• Start with simple sentences that have just one subject and one verb.
  •  Example: She sends emails. (She - subject, sends - verb)
Yes/No Questions:

• To ask a question, you can often just change the order of the words in a sentence. The verb usually comes before the subject.
  • Example: Do you work in an office? (Do - verb, you - subject)
Wh- Questions:

• Wh- questions (who, what, when, where, why, how) always start with a question word.
  • Example: What is your name? (What - question word)
Use the Correct Word Order: Sentences

Can you please let me know?
*Thanks*!

metadata.title: Use the Correct Word Order 1: sentences

params.text: Speak about the Present: Key Points

The present tense is used to talk about things that are permanent, or things that happen regularly.

Here are some tips to remember how to use the present tense:
Basic Verb Form:

• Most verbs in the present tense use the base form of the verb (the word without an "ing" ending).
  • Example: I work in an office. (work - base form)
"s" ending for He/She/It:

• For most verbs, we add an "s" to the end when the subject is he, she, or it.
  • Example: She works in a hospital. (works - present tense for "she")
"am / is /are" + Verb-ing:

• Some verbs use "am," "is," or "are" with the verb ending in "-ing" to talk about something happening now (present continuous).
  • Example: We are working on a new project. (are working - present continuous)

params.textField: Hi everyone! I'm Abigail, and I *work* in a coffee shop. I *start* my shift early in the morning. I *make* delicious coffee and tea for customers. I *also* help clean the shop and take orders. My job is fun and I *meet* new people every day!

params.text: Speak about the Present: Quiz
Choose the BEST word to complete each sentence about the present tense.
Speak about the Past: Key Points

The past tense is used to talk about actions that are finished.

Here are some tips to remember how to use the past tense:
Regular Verbs:

• Most verbs add "-ed" to the end to show they happened in the past (simple past tense).
  • Example: I worked in a restaurant last summer. (worked - past tense of "work")
Irregular Verbs:

• Some verbs have irregular past tense forms that you need to memorize. These are common verbs like "go" (went), "see" (saw), and "eat" (ate).
  • Example: We saw a great movie yesterday. (saw - past tense of "see")
Yesterday:

• A common way to talk about the past is to use the word "yesterday" with the present tense of the verb.
  • Example: He works at the office, but yesterday he worked from home. (works - present tense, worked - past tense with "yesterday")

params.text: Speak about the Past: Quiz
Please answer the following questions:
Module Summary Quiz
Test your instruction-following skills! Choose the BEST answer for each question to show what you learned in this module.

choices.question: Question 1 of 6: You want to ask your colleague a question. Which sentence is the correct order?
answers:
What is your name? 

What time the meeting starts today?

You work in this office?

choices.question: Question 2 of 6: In a simple sentence, the subject usually comes first, then the verb. Which sentence follows this order?
answers:
I work in an office. 

Work I in an office. 

The office I work in.

choices.question: Question 3 of 6: You use the present tense to talk about things that happen:
Question 4 of 6: Your colleague asks if you like coffee. How would you respond using the present tense?
answers:
Yes, I do like coffee. 

I liked coffee yesterday. 

I will like coffee later.

choices.question: Question 5 of 6: The simple past tense is used to talk about things that:
answers:
Already happened 

Happen right now 

Will happen in the future

choices.question: Question 6 of 6: You can use "yesterday" with the present tense of a verb to talk about the past. For example:
answers:
I worked at the office yesterday. 

I work at the office yesterday. 

I will work at the office yesterday.
